comments.text:
+K1productions Name recognition is often the most important factor in 
elections.  Not policy, not integrity, but name recognition...  Just goes 
to show how overwhelmingly intelligent the electorate is.  And therefore 
how easy it is for incumbents to get re-elected. 

Not to mention also showing how easy it is for the media to determine the 
outcome of many elections.  In large part all you have to do is plaster the 
candidate's name all over the newspapers/airwaves and they're basically a 
shoe in.

I also agree with you that we're being trained to believe the president is 
akin to a dictator.  And that the congress is unnecessary and just gets in 
the way.
comments.author: TheCultivatedMind

top_comment.text:
I may get a lot of angry replies for this... I really think that our spies 
should have no restrictions on when where and who they spy on.  Some of my 
 web searches are definitely embarrassing that's for sure, and I know it, 
but my embarrassment is not as important as keeping everyone I know safe. 
It is intrusive, I know. the same as having armed men walk into your house 
while you're sleeping to make sure you don't have anything that may harm 
others. I say do it .. just don't wake me up. And when you find people (T 
word) who are about to hurt us, just take em out and don't even tell us. I 
just want to live peacefully, do my job, learn, love, live , the rest 
does,'t concern me. ﻿
top_comment.author: usergroupX

comments.text:
+TheCultivatedMind So, that first part is interesting because I feel like 
nowadays the U.S. doesn't have a singular, shared interest. And if that is 
indeed the case then perhaps that is why the NSA was getting away with 
these acts for so long. Because the U.S., the way I see it, is not united 
at all.

Now, how surprised would you be if we got into another war? I don't think 
it would be too surprising. I mean, especially if it was with the countries 
you named. Although, I wasn't aware those countries were funding these (T 
word)s (how long are we going to keep this up? Haha). Maybe we already are 
in a war or wars we don't know about.

Finally, I agree that when the time calls for it then perhaps suspending 
the constitution is the right thing to do. However, now is definitely not 
one of those times. As far as we know, we're in a time of relative peace. I 
think it's noble that the CIA and NSA want to prevent terrorism before it 
starts. That's probably one of the few shared interests of this country. 
But as I said before: they are not doing that. Maybe they were doing that 
at an earlier point in time. I'm not too sure. But now they're just using 
the "we're searching for potential threats" as an excuse/cover. If they are 
really looking for threats then there shouldn't be a reason for them to 
gather and store the types of porn people watch nor any nude media they 
happen upon that belong to those same people. If they were really doing 
what they said they were doing, preventing threats, then perhaps Snowden 
wouldn't have felt the need to make what is going public. I really think 
this whole situation is strange
comments.author: blaznpookie

comments.text:
+blaznpookie I've been looking into helping the CIA and happened upon 
something that took me by surprise.  One of the advisements/requirements is 
that you shouldn't be doing things against the interests of the United 
States even if they're legal.  The part where it said 'even if they're 
legal' took me by surprise.  This could theoretically include anything we 
don't even know about; including free speech and/or repeating what networks 
like RT report.

This, among other things, makes me believe that free speech has the 
propensity to actually be damaging to the US right now.  It's sad if true, 
but it seems like we may actually be in a time of war that we really don't 
even know about.  Not only against "t words" (lol) but against those who 
fund them like Russia/China/Iran/North Korea, etc. 

Desperate times call for desperate measures in government; especially when 
preserving and protecting the United States is the most fundamental goal.  
Remember, Lincoln had to suspend the constitution during a time of civil 
war so that he could gain an advantage over the south.  FDR had to put 
Japanese Americans in internment camps out of fear they were going to 
destroy the US.  Freedom isn't exactly conducive to winning wars...  Some 
may not like it, but perhaps it actually is the best thing for us at this 
point in time.
comments.author: TheCultivatedMind

comments.text: yeah. The abuse of power combined with lack of trust is a problem for sure.
comments.author: usergroupX

comments.text:
It's unconstitutional in the first place, though. I think your suggestion 
is very logical, but another part of the problem is that the NSA is abusing 
their power. Their intention wasn't to find (T words) in the first place. 
They're simply using this power to find those embarrassing searches, 
pictures and videos. Especially anything from their political enemies, 
whether they be a citizen or a political figure.

title: CIA Spying On Congress Sparks Outrage But...
